thread.title_full: Man sentenced to 60 years in 1999 Gary killing - Post-Tribune

author: Michelle L. Quinn
title: Man sentenced to 60 years in 1999 Gary killing - Post-
text:
A high-ranking Chicago gang member was sentenced Thursday to 60 years in prison for what had been a cold case involving the kidnapping and execution-style murder of a Broadview, Ill., business owner in Gary.
Kevin Mitchell, 46, had been convicted previously of first degree murder in the 1999 shooting death of Darryl Green, a 28-year-old who was taken from the Broadview beeper store Beep the Twinz, which he co-owned with his twin brother. Mitchell, along with co-defendants Dimeyeon Cole, Menyard McAfee and Raymond Winters, were charged in 2013 after investigators found evidence linking them to an extortion scheme, according to a news release from the Cook County state's attorney's office.
At the time of the killing, according to the release, Mitchell was a leader of the Black Souls street gang and devised the plot after he found out Green and his brother had access to a lot of money. On June 18, 1999, Mitchell, Cole, McAfee and Winters kidnapped Green from the store, bound him with tape and drove to an abandoned apartment on the west side of Chicago, according to the release. They called Green's brother to demand money in exchange for Green and warned him not to involve the police, prosecutors said.
After Mitchell told the three to go back to the store to determine whether Green's family had contacted police, they said they saw what they thought were two unmarked police cars, the release said. They contacted Green's brother again, telling him to "make arrangements for your brother," then drove to Gary, beating Green in the back of the van they drove, the release said.
After arriving in Gary, Mitchell and Cole dragged Green out of the van, and Mitchell shot him twice in the head, the release said.
Winters and McAfee pleaded guilty to the crime and are serving sentences; Cole is awaiting trial, according to the release.
Michelle L. Quinn is a freelance reporter for the Post-Tribune. The Chicago Tribune contributed.
